contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Henryk Zygalski.jpg|thumb|right|125px|Henryk Zygalski about 1930]] '''Henryk Zygalski''' ({{IPA-pol|ˈxɛnrɨk zɨˈɡalski|-|Zygalski.ogg}}; 15 July 1908, [[Poznań]] – 30 August 1978, [[Liss]]) was a [[Poland|Polish]] [[mathematician]] and [[cryptologist]] who worked at breaking German [[Enigma machine|Enigma ciphers]] before and during [[World War II]]. ==Life== Zygalski was, from September 1932, a civilian [[cryptology|cryptologist]] with the [[Poland|Polish]] [[General Staff]]'s ''[[Biuro Szyfrów]]'' (Cipher Bureau), housed in the [[Pałac Saski|Saxon Palace]] in [[Warsaw]]. He worked there with fellow [[Poznan University|Poznań University]] alumni and Cipher Bureau cryptology-course graduates [[Marian Rejewski]] and [[Jerzy Różycki]]. Together they developed methods and equipment for breaking Enigma messages. [[Image:Płachta Zygalskiego - decrypting Enigma.jpg|left|thumb|Zygalski sheet]] In late 1938, in response to growing complexities in German encryption procedures, Zygalski designed the "[[Zygalski sheets|perforated sheets]]," also known as "[[Zygalski sheets]]," a manual device for finding Enigma settings. This scheme, like the earlier "[[card catalog]]," was independent of the number of connections being used in the Enigma's plugboard, or commutator. After the war he remained in exile in the [[United Kingdom]] and worked, until his retirement, as a lecturer in mathematical statistics at the [[University of Surrey]]. During this period he was prevented by the [[Official Secrets Act]] from speaking of his achievements in [[cryptology]]. He died August 30, 1978, at [[Liss]], was cremated and his ashes taken to [[London]]. [[Image:Henryk Zygalski2.jpg|thumb|140px|Zygalski in later life]] ==Honors== Shortly before his death, he was honored by the [[Polish University in Exile]] with an honorary doctorate for his role in breaking Enigma. {{clear}} ==See also== * [[Cryptanalysis of the Enigma#Enigma with a plugboard|Cryptanalysis of the Enigma]] * [[List of cryptographers]] * [[Zygalski sheets]] * [[Marian Rejewski]] * [[List of Poles#Mathematics|List of Polish mathematicians]] ==References== [[Image:Zygalski sheets (perforated sheets).jpg|right|thumb|Demonstration of [[Perforated sheets|Zygalski sheets]] at [[Bletchley Park]]]] * [[Władysław Kozaczuk]], ''Enigma: How the German Machine Cipher Was Broken, and How It Was Read by the Allies in World War II'', edited and translated by [[Christopher Kasparek]], Frederick, MD, University Publications of America, 1984, ISBN 0-89093-547-5. {{Cipher Bureau}} {{Persondata |NAME=Zygalski, Henryk |ALTERNATIVE NAMES= |SHORT DESCRIPTION=Polish mathematician and cryptologist |DATE OF BIRTH=15 July 1908 |PLACE OF BIRTH=[[Poznań]] |DATE OF DEATH=30 August 1978 |PLACE OF DEATH=[[Liss]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zygalski, Henryk}} [[Category:People from Poznań]] [[Category:Polish Army officers]] [[Category:Polish mathematicians]] [[Category:Pre-computer cryptographers]] [[Category:Polish cryptographers]] [[Category:Biuro Szyfrów]] [[Category:British people of Polish descent]] [[Category:Polish inventors]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Surrey]] [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań alumni]]
